text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_(slang)>

attachments.title: Snowflake (slang)
attachments.text: "Snowflake" is a 2010s derogatory slang term for a person, implying that they have an inflated sense of uniqueness, an unwarranted sense of entitlement, or are overly-emotional, easily offended, and unable to deal with opposing opinions. Common usages include the terms "special snowflake", "Generation Snowflake", and "snowflake" as a politicized insult.

text: <https://github.com/lefthoek/lefthoek/blob/landing/sites/landing/data/posts/the-low-end-theory.mdx>

attachments.text:
```
---
title: The Low End Theory
order: 0
author: Yeehaa
date: 2021-02-01
tags:
  - moonshots
  - exponentiality
  - entrepreneurship
  - low-hanging fruit
excerpt: |
  Everyone seems to be working on moonshots nowadays, because... well... Google
  does it. Google's approach is to take an unsolvable problem and pump a
  shitload of resources into it. Most others only copy the unsolvable problem
  bit.  True to it's cutting corner mindset, Lefthoek leaves shooting at moons
  to Google and its copy-cats and picks low-hanging fruit instead.
---

> There's a tidal wave of mysticism   
> Surging through our jet-aged generation   
> It's all designed to take us to the sky   
> 
> *Funkadelic*

In 2010, Google's Larry Page and Sergey Brin asked their buddy
[Astro](<https://hanna-barbera.fandom.com/wiki/Astro>) Teller to front an
experimental company builder mysteriously called [X](<https://x.company/>). The
single roman numeral signifies the almost religious belief in exponential logic
that both X and its mother company hold. X promises to only invest in ideas that
could make at least a 10x &mdash; Xx, get it?  &mdash; impact over the status
quo. 

The projects that X engages with are appropriately named
[moonshots](<https://www.thegeniusworks.com/2020/02/a-decade-of-moonshots-alphabet-x/>).
An term first introduced in Jules Verne's [From the Earth to the
Moon](<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/From_the_Earth_to_the_Moon>) but popularized
by president John F. Kennedy in 1961. In his famous speech, Kennedy promised
congress that he would get a man on the moon before the end of the decade.
Moreover, and equally important, the president also pledged to bring this man
back safely to earth.  Eight years and $25.4 billion dollars &mdash; that would
equate to $150 billion in today's economy &mdash; later, Apollo 11 managed to
fulfill that promise.

X takes this idea one step further by refering to itself as a moonshot factory.
The company doesn't just embark on nearly impossible missions, but aims to make
these journeys mass-producible. Its mission does not consist of solving one
*particular* impossible problem, but finding the recipe to solve *any*
impossible problem. X's blueprint for producing moonshots consists of three
simple, repeatable steps:

1. Focus on an unsolvable problem    

2. Spend a shitload of money on it  

3. Sell the resulting solution

Over a decade later, we can indisputably conclude that X's moonshot recipe has
lead to a massive amount of inspiring Wired covers. Whereas world's biggest
problems seem to be as unsolvable as 10 years ago. But hey, those [Google
Glasses](<https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/feb/19/google-glass-advice-smartglasses-glasshole#:~:text=Early%20adopters%20of%20Glass%2C%20derogatorily,for%20long%20periods%20of%20time.>)
do make you look cool while cruising your [Waymo](<https://waymo.com/>), right?

![Photo by Mariah Leynes @ Unsplash](/images/moonshot.jpg)


## Counterfeit Moon Shooters

> Rake in dividends   
> Let the money stack  
> See you copycats   
>
> *Brockhampton*

More impressive than the actual solutions that it has produced, may be the
amount of [copy cats](<https://www.moonshot-factory.eu/en/missions/>) that X has
inspired since then. Over the last decade, many an agency, incubator, or VC firm
has reinvented itself as a moonshot factory. 

While the marketing material of these counterfeit moon shooters was mostly
copied one-to-one from X's website, closer inspection reveals that they did in
fact made some small but significant changes to the original formula. In true
[Shenzen fashion](<https://nostarch.com/hardwarehackerpaperback>), they added a few features and removed some others.

1. Focus an fashionable problem    

2. Ask for a shitload of money 

As we speak, the tech world is overflowing with aspiring moon shooters searching
for generous sponsors and benevolent donors. Entrepreneurs no longer look for
investors to fund their solutions. Instead, they look for those that will let
them solve the world biggest problems. Give these aspiring Elon Musks enough
money and they will cure cancer, stop famine, and end poverty. Or so they claim.
Humanity and humility share little more than a few common letters.

![Photo by NASA @ Unsplash](/images/moonshot-2.jpg)

## Flying Low
 
> So low-key that you probably missed it   
> And yet it's so loud    
> That it stands in the crowd
>
> *A Tribe Called Quest*

Lefthoek consciously chooses not to aim for the moon. We leave pride and glory
for others, and are perfectly satisfied to do the things that need to be done
and no one else seems to care about. Moreover, we are commited to solve them
with the simplest technology possible. 

Lefthoek loves low-hanging fruit: the lower the fruit, the sweeter the juice. In
everyday tasks, there are so many small problems that could make your work a
more fun and satisfying. These could be things like:

+ Onboarding a new staff member that feels lost at the new job

+ Storing and retrieving all the interesting links that your team members shared 

+ Summarize all the messages that you missed during your vacation

Lefhoek is dedicated to solving all of these issues and many more, one at a
time: by as few means possible. That, in short, is what *the low end theory* is
all about.

```

text:
Good morning <@U01JK3M0Z36> and <@U01JK1RUG3E> :sunny:
Today I would like to share with you the activity plan for the next few weeks :muscle: I will leave for Italy on the 26th of March and will return on the 14th of April. In those weeks my support will be reduced and I will not work on Saturdays, but I will carry out the project in a flexible way during the working days.

*Design Thinking Workshop*

My plan is to finish all interviews and transcripts before I leave.
:large_green_circle: Min 5 interviews: 7.5h
:large_yellow_circle: Max 7 interviews: 10.5h
With two Saturdays I should be able to cover the minimum requests without problems.

During the interviews we will analyze the 3 main aspects of the project:
:one: Knowledge
:two: Conflicts
:three: Meeting new people
During the workshop it will be possible to deepen only one of these aspects, based on the insights found in the interviews.

_Roadmap_

:arrow_right: 06/03 <@U01L4C2781W> <@U01JK1RUG3E> Preparation and finalization of the interview, which will last 30 min max.

:arrow_right: 13/03 <@U01L4C2781W> Interview participants and transcribe the interviews. Each interview plus transcript takes about 1.5h.

:arrow_right: 20/03 <@U01L4C2781W> Interview the rest of participants and transcription.

:pencil2: I will draw the affinity diagram while I am in Italy, so that everything is ready when I return.

:arrow_right: 14/04 <@U01L4C2781W> Affinity diagram at 42 and final discussion on the patterns I found in the research.

:arrow_right: 15/04 11-13 <@U01L4C2781W> <@U01JK1RUG3E> Workshop Day 1 :muscle:

:arrow_right: 22/04 11-13 <@U01L4C2781W> <@U01JK1RUG3E> Workshop Day 2 :tada:

*Visual Content for the deck and LinkedIn*

Due to the tight deadline of the workshop I can't continue my visual support activity, especially the deck, which takes longer due to the complexity of the graphics. I believe it is a priority to find someone who can help produce this content.
<@U01JK3M0Z36> Did you get an answer in your search for the designer?

elements.text: Good morning
and
Today I would like to share with you the activity plan for the next few weeks

I will leave for Italy on the 26th of March and will return on the 14th of April. In those weeks my support will be reduced and I will not work on Saturdays, but I will carry out the project in a flexible way during the working days.
Design Thinking Workshop
My plan is to finish all interviews and transcripts before I leave.
Min 5 interviews: 7.5h

Max 7 interviews: 10.5h
With two Saturdays I should be able to cover the minimum requests without problems.

During the interviews we will analyze the 3 main aspects of the project:
Knowledge
Conflicts

Meeting new people
During the workshop it will be possible to deepen only one of these aspects, based on the insights found in the interviews.
Roadmap
Preparation and finalization of the interview, which will last 30 min max.
Interview participants and transcribe the interviews. Each interview plus transcript takes about 1.5h.
Interview the rest of participants and transcription.
I will draw the affinity diagram while I am in Italy, so that everything is ready when I return.
Affinity diagram at 42 and final discussion on the patterns I found in the research.
Workshop Day 1
Workshop Day 2
Visual Content for the deck and LinkedIn

Due to the tight deadline of the workshop I can't continue my visual support activity, especially the deck, which takes longer due to the complexity of the graphics. I believe it is a priority to find someone who can help produce this content.
Did you get an answer in your search for the designer?
